channel.title: SAVE Wheelchair Trans
channel.description: We provide secure and reliable wheelchair accessible transportation services in Greater Toronto Area and beyond. Call 647-239-5467.

item.title: Home
item.dc:creator: chang
item.content:encoded:
Wheelchair Accessible Transportation Services in Toronto.

We are dedicated drivers trained to provide non-emergency wheelchair accessible transportation services to people with special needs and disabilities. We operate in Greater Toronto Area and beyond.

Your Satisfaction is Our Goal

Need reliable wheelchair accessible transportation services? Look no further.

Your Needs

Our customers always come first. You can rely on us for your travel needs:
  • Medical Appointments
  • Dialysis
  • Rehabilitation
  • Physiotherapy
  • Social Activities
  • School Activities

Our Services

The benefits of our services include:
  • Professional Staff Members
  • Wheelchair Accessible Vans
  • 24 / 7 Services
  • Flexible Door-to-Door Service
  • Best Rate
  • Maximum 5 Passengers
  • Provide Wheelchair if Needed
  • Senior 10% Discount

Contact Us

Call us for inquiries or reservations.
  • 647-239-5467 (Willy)
  • 647-802-8727 (Peter)
  • 647-896-7400 (Chang)
Email us at info@savewheelchairtrans.com.

item.title: About
item.dc:creator: chang
item.content:encoded:
About Us

We, at SAVE Wheelchair Trans, provide non-emergency wheelchair accessible transportation services in Greater Toronto Area and surrounding regions including Barrie, Kitchener, and Niagara Falls.

SAVE Wheelchair Trans is owned and operated by a group of dedicated drivers trained to support passengers with special needs and disabilities. Our drivers will take your reservation calls, will get you anywhere you need to go in Ontario, and also will look forward to providing you a ride again next time.

Our mission is to provide high-quality, secure, and reliable services for our clients. We strive for your satisfaction from your doorstep to your destination. We ensure that you feel comfortable and safe while the service is provided. We also operate 24 hours and 7 days a week, so that we are always ready to get you to wherever you want, whenever you need.

Why Should You Choose Us

Our clients are important to us. Your satisfaction is our top-most priority. In order to satisfy your mobility needs, we are delivering high-quality, secure, and reliable transportation services.

Our services are based on the industry competitive flat-rate pricing structure. When you call, you will be given a quote detailing the exact cost of the trip, which is calculated using the total distance. We also offer exclusive 10% discount to seniors.

Our drivers are committed to satisfy the mobility needs of our clients with high-quality customer care and safety. You will be comfortable and safe during the trip, and you will feel as if you would be in your own vehicle.

We provide flexible door-to-door transportation services 24 hours and 7 days a week. You can rely on us to go anywhere, whenever you need. We also provide wheelchairs upon request. Just let us know and we will bring it to your location.

Our clients always come first. We offer the highest quality of transportation services with competitive flat-rate pricing. Our drivers are committed to ensure that we provide comfortable and secure services to our clients. Also you can rely on us 24 hours and 7 days a week, flexible and door-to-door services.

Where We Can Go

Our wheelchair transportation services cover the entire GTA and surrounding regions including Barrie, Kitchener, and Niagara Falls.

item.title: Wheelchair on Google Trends
item.dc:creator: chang
item.content:encoded: Which city has the highest demand for wheelchair taxi in Canada? Which countries do people search for wheelchair transportation on the internet? At least Google Trends sheds some lights on trying to answer some of these questions. Google exposes where and when the search happened the most given the search keyword. I tried 'wheelchair'. [caption id="" align="alignnone" width="500"] search traffic for 'wheelchair'[/caption] The page shows 'wheelchair' worldwide search traffic since 2004 to present. We can see that the traffic came mostly from United States, but a lot of traffic also came from Canada as well. I wanted to see which city people searched for 'wheelchair', so I clicked "City" link to see the data. [caption id="" align="alignnone" width="398"] The list of cities from where people searched for 'wheelchair'[/caption] Note that the number besides the blue bar represent the search volume relative to the highest point on the chart, which is always 100. So in this case the search traffic for 'wheelchair' from Toronto is about two third of the traffic coming from Dublin. And Toronto is the only city listed here. We can see from the page that wheelchair search traffic is steady, and also a lot of people who searched for 'wheelchair' usually also searched for keywords like 'wheelchair accessible', 'wheelchair rental', 'electric wheelchair', etc. Since we are a wheelchair accessible transportation company, I typed 'wheelchair taxi' to see what is the search trend for this keyword. [caption id="" align="alignnone" width="500"] search trend for 'wheelchair taxi'[/caption] Surprisingly there isn't much traffic for this throughout Canada, but the most of traffic comes from British Columbia and Ontario only. The city-level information is not available for this keyword. I think the reason is that the search volume for this keyword is substantially smaller than 'wheelchair' or other popular keywords, so the information is too granular to expose to public. The keyword for 'wheelchair transportation' shows the similar graph. [caption id="" align="alignnone" width="500"] keyword 'wheelchair transportation'[/caption] The pattern looks similar to 'wheelchair taxi' except that the traffic is now highly concentrated on Ontario. Still overall the search volume is very small. I think there are not much data to draw any conclusion in this case because there aren't much traffic for wheelchair transportation in general. But I think Google Trends is a handy tool to help assess what people search for the most and quickly see where and when people look for stuff.

item.title: What Makes a Good Wheelchair Ramp?
item.dc:creator: chang
item.content:encoded:
Wheelchair-accessible ramps are essential for easier access to buildings and stores that have doorsteps and stairs to their entrances. Accessibility for Ontarians with Disabilities Act (AODA) mandates that all the businesses regardless of their sizes ensure their services are accessible to people with disabilities. And having wheelchair-accessible ramps could remove physical barriers to enter their businesses, which is the first step to comply with AODA. AODA, however, does not regulate the wheelchair ramp designs, so we often see many poorly designed ramps that not only cause negative experiences but also pose a barrier that can be dangerous to people. So, what can be a good wheelchair accessible ramp? How should we install the ramps so that they really benefit people in wheelchairs? There are few things to consider, which are 1) slope, 2) landing experiences, 3) visibility, and 4) maintenance.

Slope

The ramp slope should be low enough to make the climb easier for wheelchair users. If the angle is too steep then it will make the ramp difficult to climb and also could be dangerous. There is currently no regulation regarding the wheelchair ramp slope in Canada[1], but other countries including United States and United Kingdom require a 1:12 slope for wheelchair ramps. This means 1'' of rise requires 12'' of ramp. [caption id="" align="alignnone" width="500"] It is common that slopes "go around" the stairs to have a lower slope and longer length.[/caption]

Landing Experience

Landing experience is as much important as climb up the ramp. Usually the landing side of the ramp should have enough space to rest and proceed towards the building entrance. We often notice that many businesses do not provide good landing experiences even if they provide wheelchair ramps on their doorsteps. [caption id="" align="alignnone" width="500"] Wheelchair users will have hard time pulling open these doors while on the ramp.[/caption]

Visibility

The wheelchair ramps should be installed close to the stairs and must be visible and apparent to people who need them. Ideally the wheelchair users should be able to find the ramps without any sign, but if the ramps are somehow hard to find due to constructions or temporary disruptions, there must be a sign indicating an alternate route to wheelchair ramps.

Maintenance

Winter involves heavy snowfall in Greater Toronto Area and Ontario in general. Maintenance is necessary to ensure that there is no snow accumulation that could block both the approach and the landing of the ramp. This problem could be seen mostly in the sidewalk ramps, where snow is often plowed onto the sidewalk to build the banks and block the ramps. [caption id="" align="alignnone" width="500"] After heavy snowfall, the hard-packed snow could block the sidewalk ramps.[/caption] Slope, landing experience, visibility, and maintenance are some of the things to consider when installing the accessible ramps. It is a bit surprising that Ontario (or Canada) does not provide any regulation on how the ramps should be installed. Since no regulation is enforced there are many ramps out there that are just inadequate to use. The wheelchair ramps at least should meet the points mentioned above to provide better accessibility to wheelchair users. [1] In fact, Ontario does specify 1:12 ratio for the ramps in the billing code: Ontario building code.

item.title: Accessibility for Ontarians with Disabilities Act (AODA)
item.dc:creator: chang
item.content:encoded:
[caption id="attachment_88" align="alignnone" width="300"] The AODA[/caption] There is a news regarding the businesses trying to comply with the Accessibility for the Ontarians with Disabilities Act (AODA), or there is a more specific example of Starbucks announcing the commitment to comply with the AODA. The AODA is, as its name implies, an Act to improve the accessibility for people with disabilities in Ontario. But how does it improve the accessibility? We already have the similar Bill: the Ontarians with Disabilities Act (ODA), which was enacted before the AODA. So what is the difference between the AODA and the ODA? How does the AODA enforce the accessibility? In this post we will talk about the purpose of the AODA, how the AODA complements the ODA, and what is its implication for wheelchair users in Ontario.

What is the AODA and when was it enacted?

The AODA is the Act to mandate the accessibility standards and regulations to every business in Ontario to improve the accessibility for people with disabilities using their services. The AODA has been enacted in 2005, and became the law as of January 1, 2012.

The difference between the ODA and the AODA.

The ODA has been enacted in 2002 to "improve opportunities for persons with disabilities and to provide for their involvement in the identification, removal, and prevention of barriers to their full participation in the life of the province". The Bill mandates the government's commitment to remove the barriers that people with disabilities experience to participating in the society events. The problems with this Bill, however, are that first of all, the Bill did not specify the time-frame for the government to create the barrier-free environment. Secondly, this Bill only applies to the public sectors and left the private sectors unaffected by the Bill. And lastly, the Bill requires the government sectors to prepare accessibility plans as part of their annual planning process, but does not enforce them to implement the plans. So here comes the AODA; the AODA has been enacted in 2005 to complement the ODA with deadlines, enforcement, and penalties. The purpose of the AODA is to develop, implement, and enforce accessibility standards to every organization in Ontario with respect to goods, services, facilities, employment, buildings, structures, and premises, by January 1, 2025.

The Bill Enforcement

The AODA enforces five standards: Customer Service, Transportation, Information & Communications, Employment, and Built Environment. The AODA requires organizations to create accessibility plans indicating how the organizations will implement to meet the regulation for each accessibility standard by the designated deadline. The Act details the procedure the individual organization should take to propose the initial plan, determine the time-frame, and finalize the process. The Act also specifies the government inspection rules and the penalties of the organizations that fail to meet the standard by the deadline. Each standard has different deadline. For example, the deadline for the Customer Service standard was January 1, 2012. This means that all the organizations in Ontario must now be compliant with the Customer Service standards since 2012.

The Current Status of the AODA Compliance

As mentioned above, the accessibility standards for Customer Service has been rolled out and its compliance is mandatory for all the organizations in Ontario, whether they be government, business, or charity organizations. Other four standards are in progress to set the schedules of compliance. For Employment standard, the current schedule is that the Government of Ontario must be compliant by January 1, 2013, large public sector organizations by January 1, 2014, small public sector organizations by January 1, 2015, large organizations by January 1, 2016, and small organizations by January 1, 2017.

The Implication to the Wheelchair Users in Ontario

The Accessibility Standards for Customer Service is the standard, which applies to any organization that provides goods and services to customers. It sets out the obligations that the organizations must now provide their goods and services in a way that is accessible to people with disabilities. For example, all the restaurants in Ontario should already have established their businesses accessible to customers in wheelchairs. Toronto Transit Commision (TTC) has made their Accessible Customer Service Policy public. Transportation Standards will be rolled out to public transportation providers between 2011 and 2017, and every transportation service provider should ensure that all of the transportation vehicles be equipped with lifting devices or ramps by January 1, 2013. Also they should not charge people with disabilities higher fare. Built Environment Standards focus on removing barriers in public spaces and buildings. For the public spaces, however, the standard only applies to new construction and major changes to existing features. This excludes the already built hiking trails and parks that are not wheelchair-accessible.

Resources

  • Text of the Accessibility for Ontarians with Disabilities Act.
  • Text of the Ontarians with Disabilities Act.
  • Text of the Accessibility Standards for Customer Service.

item.title: Accessible Routes to Finch TTC Station Subway Platform
item.dc:creator: chang
item.content:encoded:
[caption id="attachment_145" align="alignnone" width="300"] Finch TTC Station[/caption] Finch TTC Station is the most northernmost station in Yonge-subway line and is wheelchair-accessible. I am not a wheelchair user, but I wanted to see what are the wheelchair accessible routes to the subway platform from outside if I were on a wheelchair. There are about 6 pedestrian entrances to the station, and half of them have accessible elevators installed: Kiss-N-Ride, Go Finch Bus Terminal, and North American Life Centre. [caption id="" align="alignnone" width="375"] An elevator next to Kiss-N-Ride.[/caption] [caption id="" align="alignnone" width="500"] An elevator next to Go Finch Bus Terminal.[/caption] The main entrance to the North American Life Centre is not wheelchair-accessible, so you have to go around the building to use the side entrances (there are two of them) that are accessible. [caption id="" align="alignnone" width="500"] Do not enter through this entrance because it is not wheelchair-accessible.[/caption] The following video clips show how to get to the subway platform from those entrances. http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=D1Gn55p4xsY http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=IJ1boAcLoXo The followings are the two clips from the two side entrances of North American Life Centre. http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3N1034YzoUw http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=VqKYQmyb0JI As you can see in the clips there is a lift in the stair passage from the lower level of North American Life Centre to the lower concourse level of the station. The problem with this lift is that you cannot get it to your level if it is on the other side. http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Q20clUbej5I The landing instruction of the lift seems outdated or does not clearly explain how I could get the lift to my level. The only button I did not press is "Call for assistance", which I would find it annoying if I had to call the service attendant every time I use the lift. Once you are inside the paid area, you can see the elevator next to the fare gate that leads to the subway platform, and you can also find the washroom, which is wheelchair-accessible. There are one wheelchair stall and two non-wheelchair stalls. The wheelchair stall is neither particularly cleaner nor dirtier than the other stalls. There is also another elevator that leads to the upper level, where you take another elevator to the bus platform. I took another movie clip from the bus platform to the subway platform. http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9OY8ASFCOlw I am not a wheelchair user and there would be more stuff that I missed which the actual wheelchair users would find inconvenient, but I think there are two issues that need to be improved:
  1. The lift needs to be fixed unless it is intentional to call for assistance every time the lift is used.
  2. The North American Life Centre does not have a clear sign how to enter the building with wheelchairs. Either the building should make its main entrance wheelchair-accessible, or it should provide an explicit sign for its alternative accessible entrances.

item.title: The Community Ramp Project - StopGap
item.dc:creator: chang
item.content:encoded: I originally found the StopGap project from an article in Toronto Star, and I found this project truly inspiring. StopGap is a non-profit organization to remove the physical barriers so that every person can access every space without worries. And their first project is the community ramp project: build bright colourful ramps with donated materials and install them at the stores that are willing to have the ramps in their doorsteps. What I really like about this project is the attention that this little ramp can get; the ramp itself is probably not the best wheelchair ramp design ever, but its vivid colour with StopGap website address on it attracts people's attentions walking by. Also I could see that these ramps also give positive images to the local stores that have them. I think this project could raise awareness of accessibility issues, which is what we need to make our neighbourhood more accessible. Here are some pictures that we took while we were at Stouffville. StopGap is expanding to install the ramps on other towns, and you can see the full list of locations here. [caption id="attachment_166" align="alignnone" width="300"] yellow ramp.[/caption] [caption id="" align="alignnone" width="300"] ramps[/caption] [caption id="" align="alignnone" width="300"] red ramp[/caption]   [caption id="" align="alignnone" width="300"] stouffville go station[/caption]

item.title: Financial Assistance for People with Disabilities
item.dc:creator: chang
item.content:encoded:
There are several programs that provide financial supports to people with disabilities. For instance, Registered Disability Savings Plan (RDSP) can provide up to $90,000 for the entire lifetime. Canada Pension Plan (CPP) Disability Benefits is a monthly payment (~$841.95/month, 2012-basis) to people who are eligible for the benefit. Grant for Students with Permanent Disabilities provides students $2,000 / year to help cover their tuition expenses.

Registered Disability Savings Plan

This is a long-term savings plan available for individuals who are under 60 and eligible for the Disability Tax Credit. It is similar to a Registered Retirement Savings Plan (RRSP) in a way that the earnings from your savings will remain tax-free until you withdraw money out of the RDSP later. You need to have Social Insurance Number (SIN) to be considered eligible and the lifetime contribution limit is $200,000, although there is no annual limit. The government provides two additional financial support programs that could match your RDSP savings up to maximum $90,000 over your lifetime: Canada Disability Savings Grant and Canada Disability Savings Bond.

Canada Disability Savings Grant

Canada Disability Savings Grant (CDSG) is a matching grant that the government deposits into your RDSP. The maximum grant amount is $3,500 / year and the lifetime amount is $70,000, but the actual amount depends on the family income and the amount of annual savings. If the family income is below $87,123, then the government gives $3,500 for $1,500 contributed a year. You may contribute more than $1,500, but there is no more matching grant beyond $1,500. If the family income is above $87,123, then the government gives $1,000 for $1,000 contributed a year. You may contribute more than $1,000, but there is no more matching grant beyond $1,000. You can receive the government grant up to $70,000 for your lifetime.

Canada Disability Savings Bond

Canada Disability Savings Bond (CDSB) is a program for low-income and modest-income families whose annual income is below $43,561. The government will deposit $1,000 / year to your RDSP if your income is below $25,356, and this amount will decrease as your annual income increases. If your annual income is above $43,561, there is no more benefit. You do not need to make any contribution to your RDSP to receive the benefit. You can receive the bond amount up to $20,000 for your lifetime.

Canada Pension Plan Disability Benefit

Canada Pension Plan (CPP) Disability Benefit is a monthly benefit available to individuals who has made enough contributions to the CPP, but could not work any longer because of disability. You may be considered eligible if you are under 65, stopped working because of a medical condition, and has contributed to the CPP while working. The actual monthly amount depends on how much you have contributed to the CPP, but the average amount was $841.95 / month on 2012, and the maximum amount was $1212.90 / month. The amount will be re-adjusted on January every year if there are increases in the cost of living.

Grant for Students with Permanent Disabilities

There is a grant available to students studying in universities and post-secondary institutions. If you apply and qualify for a Canada Student Loan, you can be eligible for receiving this grant as well. You can receive $2,000 per academic year to help cover your tuition, books, and accommodation costs.
